properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Total snowfall: locally 10 to 15 cm in snow squalls. Locations: western Newfoundland from Port aux Basques to the Bay of Islands. Time span: continuing until this evening. Remarks: Flurries and snow squalls will continue throughout the day. The snow squalls will taper off this evening with flurries lingering throughout the night. Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-20T00:47:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-19T08:48:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0715224167.2020
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Bay St. George
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Total snowfall: locally 10 to 15 cm in snow squalls. Locations: along the Burgeo Highway. Time span: continuing until this evening. Remarks: Flurries and snow squalls will continue throughout the day, mainly affecting the Burgeo Highway, with just a few flurries along the south coast. The snow squalls will taper off early this evening with flurries lingering throughout the night. Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow with just a few kilometres are common. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-19T19:59:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-19T08:47:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2808537845.2020
Area: Burgeo - Ramea
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds gusting up to 80 km/h are expected today. Southwesterly winds are expected to strengthen this morning with gusts to 70 or 80 km/h possible by late this morning. The strongest wind gusts are expected near Lake Erie. These strong winds are expected throughout the afternoon and into the evening hours before easing slightly by later in the evening. These winds have the potential to toss loose objects, break tree branches and lead to power outages. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-20T01:29:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-19T09:30:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4242093470.2020
Area: Simcoe - Delhi - Norfolk, Dunnville - Caledonia - Haldimand, St. Catharines - Grimsby - Northern Niagara Region, Niagara Falls - Welland - Southern Niagara Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog has formed overnight at Qikiqtarjuaq and is expected to persist until later this morning. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-19T17:02:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-19T09:08:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1110397039.2020
Area: Qikiqtarjuaq
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A band of heavy snow is moving through central Alberta tonight. The northern extent of the heavy snow is expected to be along or just south of Highway 16. Over the city of Edmonton total snowfall amounts are expected to vary with the highest amounts falling in the south, where near 10 cm is expected by Thursday afternoon. Snow will taper off through the day on Thursday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-19T22:14:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-19T06:15:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1749839468.2020

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Total snowfall: generally 2 to 4 cm with locally up to 10 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: near 50 km/h. Locations: King's County P.E.I., Iles-de-la-Madeleine, and western Cape Breton. Time span: today. Remarks: Snow squalls and flurries will taper off from west to east today ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Freezing drizzle continues in Flin Flon and Thompson this evening but should begin to taper off after midnight. ### Freezing drizzle can produce thin, hard-to-detect layers of ice. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-19T13:59:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-19T03:23:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3318932730.2020
